questions.text: A 31 -year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of persistent abdominal cramping, diarrhea, and rectal pain. During the past 2 weeks, she has had up to 4 small volumed, blood-tinged stools with mucus daily. She has also had intermittent fevers and a 4.5-kg weight loss during this time. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg. The abdomen is soft, and there is tenderness to palpation of the left lower quadrant with guarding but no rebound. Bowel sounds are normal. The stool is brown, and a test for occult blood is positive. Flexible sigmoidoscopy shows a granular, hyperemic, and friable rectal mucosa that bleeds easily on contact. Which of the following is this patient at greatest risk of developing?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Colorectal cancer This patient's episodes of bloody diarrhea with mucus, tenesmus, and abdominal pain, in combination with the endoscopic findings of an inflamed, friable mucosa with rectal involvement , are consistent with a diagnosis of ulcerative colitis . Patients with ulcerative colitis have an increased risk of colorectal cancer, with risk factors including the extent of colitis, the duration of disease, and the histological severity of inflammation. Eight to ten years after the initial diagnosis of ulcerative colitis, patients should receive colonoscopies with biopsies every 1–3 years to screen for Colorectal cancer.

Highyeild:

Colorectal Cancer: Colorectal cancer is the second most common cause of cancer death in the UK, with approximately 42,000 new cases diagnosed each year. Colon cancer represents about two-thirds of cases, while rectal cancer accounts for the remaining one-third. Men are more affected than women, with 56% of cases occurring in men. The adenoma-carcinoma sequence is the prevailing theory on how most colorectal cancers develop. The APC gene is mutated early in the carcinogenesis process and is present in two-thirds of colonic adenomas. K-ras mutations are more commonly found in larger lesions, indicating a later occurrence in the mutagenesis process. The p53 gene is frequently mutated in carcinomas but not in adenomas, making it a marker of invasion.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) is a thrombotic microangiopathy and complication of diarrheal bacterial infection, particularly with Entero hemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC). Though this patient has a 1-month history of diarrhea, the typical presentation of HUS is the triad of thrombocytopenia, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and impaired renal function that develops 5–10 days after the onset of diarrheal illness. Additionally, HUS typically affects young children. Option: B. Oral ulcers are a typical complication of Crohn disease, an inflammatory bowel disease that also causes abdominal cramping and diarrhea. Unlike ulcerative colitis, which only affects the colon and rectum, Crohn disease can involve any part of the gastrointestinal tract from mouth to anus. However, in Crohn disease, the rectum is usually spared, and the condition mostly presents with watery, nonbloody stools and with just a slight increase in stool frequency as opposed to this patient showing bloody stools with mucus and a marked increase in stool frequency. Furthermore, RLQ pain is more common in Crohn disease. Option: C. Gastric cancer has multiple risk factors, but ulcerative colitis is not among them. Risk factors for gastric cancer include a diet rich in nitrates and salt, alcohol use, H. pylori infection, and gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).

Extraedge:

A recent international consortium identified four consensus molecular subtypes (CMSs) of colorectal cancer based on gene expression analysis in over 4000 patients. CMS1 is characterized by MSI, a feature of Lynch syndrome, which may occur sporadically, mainly in right-sided tumors. CMS2 is characterized by WNT and MYC signaling activation. CMS3 is characterized by metabolic dysregulation. CMS4 is characterized by transforming growth factor beta activation.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-week history of colicky abdominal pain and diarrhea. He has bowel movements 10–12 times daily; the stool contains blood and mucus. He constantly has the urge to defecate. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the abdomen shows diffuse tenderness to palpation. The serum concentration of C-reactive protein is 20 mg/L (N<10). A colonoscopy shows a bleeding, ulcerated rectal mucosa with several pseudopolyps. Which of the following is this patient at greatest risk of developing?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Colorectal cancer The patient's symptoms are consistent with a diagnosis of Ulcerative Colitis Patients with ulcerative colitis have an increased risk of colorectal cancer, with the disease's extent, duration, and histologic severity correlating with the degree of risk. Eight to ten years after the initial diagnosis of ulcerative colitis, patients should receive colonoscopies with biopsies every 1–3 years to screen for colorectal cancer.

Highyeild:

Colorectal cancer The Macroscopic appearance of colon tumors can take different forms Annular tumors may cause obstructive symptoms, while ulcerating tumors may cause bleeding Most large bowel cancers arise from the left colon, specifically the rectum (38%), sigmoid (21%), and descending colon (4%) Cancer of the ascending colon (5%), caecum (12%), transverse colon (5.5%), flexures (2-3%), and appendix (0.5%) are less common Microscopically, these tumors are columnar cell adenocarcinomas The Spread of colonic cancer can occur through local means, lymphatics, bloodstream (hematogenous), or peritoneal cavity (trans coelomic spread) Direct spread can be longitudinal or radial Radial spread may occur retroperitoneally into the ureter, duodenum, and posterior abdominal wall muscles or intraperitoneally into adjacent organs or the anterior abdominal wall.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Colonic granulomas are often seen in Crohn's disease, an inflammatory bowel disease that causes abdominal cramping and diarrhea. Unlike ulcerative colitis, which only affects the colon and rectum, Crohn's disease can involve any part of the gastrointestinal tract from mouth to anus (the most commonly applied site is the terminal ileum). However, Crohn's disease usually spares the rectum and typically features grossly non-bloody diarrhea (although stool is often positive for occult blood). In addition, ileocolonoscopy in a patient with active Crohn's disease would more likely show linear ulcers, pinpoint lesions, a characteristic cobblestone appearance of the mucosa, and perianal fissures or fistulas. Option: C. Gastric cancer has multiple risk factors, but ulcerative colitis is not among them. Risk factors for gastric cancer include a diet rich in nitrates and salt, alcohol use, H. pylori infection, and gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Option: D. Pancreatic cancer has multiple risk factors, but ulcerative colitis is not among them. Risk factors for pancreatic cancer include smoking, chronic pancreatitis, alcohol use, H. pylori infection, and inherited genetic syndromes.

Extraedge:

The involvement of lymph nodes by the tumor typically progresses from the nearest lymph nodes along the lymphatics to the central nodes. Still, this process may only sometimes occur in an orderly manner. The hematogenous spread of colon cancer commonly occurs in the liver via th e portal vein. One-third of patients have liver metastases at diagnosis, and 50% develop metastases at some point, accounting for most deaths. The lungs are the following most common site of metastatic disease Spread to the ovaries, brain, kidney, and bone is less common Colorectal cancer can also spread from the serosa of the bowel or via subperitoneal lymphatics to other structures within the peritoneal cavity, such as the peritoneum, ovary, and omentum

questions.text: Which Ulcerative Colitis patients have an enhanced risk of developing cancer?

options.label: A
options.text: Those who have had the disease since adulthood

options.label: B
options.text: Those who have had the disease for over ten years.

options.label: C
options.text: Those who have had a mild first attack.

options.label: D
options.text: Those who have only the rectum involved.

questions.correct_answer: B. Those who have had the disease for over ten years.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Those who have had the disease for over ten years. Patients with inflammatory bowel disease, particularly UC, have an increased risk of developing carcinoma, the risk increasing with the duration of the disease; after ten years, the risk is 1% increasing to 10%–15% at 20 years and 30% at 30 years.

Highyeild:

Cancer Risk in Ulcerative Colitis: The risk of cancer in ulcerative colitis increases with the duration of the disease. After ten years from diagnosis, the risk is approximately 1%, increasing to 10-15% at 20 years and 20% at 30 years. Patients with pancolitis lasting more than ten years should be enrolled in endoscopic screening programs to detect dysplasia, which is predictive of increased cancer risk. The value of screening programs is somewhat controversial, as most patients with UC who develop cancer (approximately 3.5% of all patients) do so between attendances for screening colonoscopy. Malignant change in UC patients can be multifocal or submucosal, often atypical and high grade, and may occur in fat mucosa or a dysplasia-associated lesion or mass (DALM).

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Those who have had the disease since childhood {not since adulthood], have an enhanced risk of developing cancer Option: C. Those who had a severe first attack {not mild}have an enhanced risk of developing cancer Option: D. In whom the entire colon is involved (pancolitis){not only rectum } have an enhanced risk for carcinoma. Therefore patients with pancolitis of >10 years are entered into annual colonoscopic surveillance. Colonoscopic screening is a routine when multiple biopsies are taken to detect dysplasia, which can occur in a flat mucosa or in dysplasia-associated lesions or mass (DALMs).

Extraedge:

Colonoscopic surveillance with dye spray (chromoendoscopy) or multiple biopsies every 10 cm should be used to look for subtle mucosal abnormalities. Patients with UC and sclerosing cholangitis are also at significantly greater risk of developing large bowel cancer. Regular screening and surveillance are necessary to detect any changes early in these high-risk patients.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination after a colonoscopy showed 42 hamartomatous polyps. The physical examination findings are shown in the photograph. Which of the following conditions is most likely to develop in this patient
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pancreatic Carcinoma The patient findings are consistent with Peutz Jeghers syndrome. Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS) is a rare autosomal dominant condition caused by a hyperactive serine-threonine kinas e due to a gain of function mutation on the STK11 gene on chromosome 19 . Patients with PJS develop melanotic macules on the lips , buccal mucosa, genitalia, palms, and soles as well as gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps characterized by normal colonic epithelium and branching muscularis mucosae. Possible complications of the hamartomatous polyps include bleeding and intussusception . Individuals with PJS are also at increased risk of colorectal, pancreatic, ovarian, and breast cancer malignancies.

Highyeild:

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is characterized by multiple polyps in the small intestine, and to a lesser extent, the colon and rectum. Melanin spots on the buccal mucosa and lips are often observed in patients with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome. The polyps in Peutz-Jeghers syndrome are hamartomas and are not typically associated with an increased risk of malignancy, but carcinoma may occasionally develop. Surgery for Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is usually reserved for patients with symptoms such as obstruction or bleeding or those who develop adenomatous features in their polyps. Screening for Peutz-Jeghers syndrome involves a baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy at age 20, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy . Clinicians should also screen patients for extraintestinal malignancies , such as breast, upper gastrointestinal tract, pancreas, cervix, ovaries, and testicles.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is not associated with an increased risk of mandibular osteomas. Mandibular osteomas and soft tissue tumors (e.g., desmoid tumors, sebaceous cysts) are associated with Gardner syndrome, a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), which would present with colonic polyps. However, the polyps in FAP would be adenomatous rather than hamartomatous, and patients with FAP typically have thousands of polyps. Option: B. Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is not associated with an increased risk of pheochromocytoma. The risk of pheochromocytoma is increased in neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1), von Hippel-Lindau disease (VHL), and multiple endocrine neoplasias (MEN) types 2. NF1 can cause hyperpigmented macules (café au lait spots), intestinal neuromas, and hamartomatous nodules in the iris (Lisch nodules). Still, the café au lait spots would be seen on the trunk in association with cutaneous neurofibromas, and hamartomatous intestinal polyps would not be expected. MEN type 2A can cause intestinal neuromas, and VHL can cause cavernous intestinal hemangiomas, but neither MEN type 2A, nor VHL would be associated with hamartomatous polyps or perioral hyperpigmented macules. Option: C. Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is not associated with an increased risk of medulloblastoma . Brain tumors such as medulloblastoma and gliomas are associated with Turcot syndrome, a familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) variant that would manifest with colonic polyps. However, the polyps in FAP would be adenomatous rather than hamartomatous, and patients with FAP typically have thousands of polyps.

Extraedge:

PJS exhibits autosomal dominant inheritance, with chromosome 19p13.3 encoding the serine-threonine kinase LKB1/STK11. Pseudoinvasion (epithelial cell trapping) is sometimes noted in polyps > 3cm.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 7.2-kg weight loss over the past six months. She went to Mexico for two months this year. For the last four weeks, she has also had intermittent constipation and bloating. She has never smoked. She drinks one glass of wine daily. She appears thin. Her temperature is 38.3°C (101°F), her pulse is 80/min, and her blood pressure is 136/78 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The abdomen is distended, and the liver is palpable 4 cm below the right costal margin with a hard, mildly tender nodule in the left lobe. The test of the stool for occult blood is positive A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Metastatic colorectal cancer This patient presents with weight loss, low-grade fever, lower gastrointestinal complaints (i.e., constipation), and evidence of blood in the stool (positive stool occult blood test). This contrast-enhanced CT scan shows multiple hypodense solitary lesions with peripheral rim enhancement in both lobes of the liver, characteristic of hepatic metastases. These features suggest a primary colorectal malignancy that has metastasized to the liver, the most frequent metastatic site for this condition. The palpable hepatomegaly with a hard nodule and mildly deranged liver function tests are caused by the metastatic deposits.

Highyeild:

Colorectal Carcinoma: Surgery is recommended only for patients with recurrence of colorectal carcinoma with isolated metastasis in the liver, lung, ovaries, or anastomotic sites. Pulmonary Metastasis: Prognosis is based on several factors, including the number and size of metastases, lymph node involvement, additional metastatic sites, and pre-thoracotomy CEA levels. Primary disease-free survival or colorectal cancer stage does not significantly affect survival rates after thoracotomy. Prophylactic Bilateral Oophorectomy: It may be recommended for postmenopausal women with a history of colorectal cancer. The incidence of ovarian cancer is five times higher in women with a history of colorectal cancer. The prevention of primary ovarian cancer is considered to be the main benefit of prophylactic bilateral oophorectomy.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. A liver hemangioma, when symptomatic, causes upper gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., abdominal pain, nausea, early satiety) in contrast to this patient's primarily lower gastrointestinal symptoms (intermittent constipation with abdominal distention). Furthermore, liver hemangiomas do not cause weight loss or blood in the stool. On contrast-enhanced CT scan, a liver hemangioma can also appear as a hypodense lesion with peripheral rim enhancement but are usually solitary. Option: B. Intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma (IHC) may present with weight loss and hepatomegaly in the absence of cholestasis (jaundice, pruritus), as in this patient. On contrast-enhanced CT scans, a mass-forming IHC is seen as a hypodense lesion with peripheral rim enhancement. However, IHCs are usually solitary, and the center of the lesion shows heterogenic echogenicity (compared to the anechoic centers in this patient) and dilation of the intrahepatic bile ducts. IHCs do not cause constipation or occult blood in stool, and ALP is usually elevated in IHC but is normal in this patient. Option: C. Echinococcus granulosus is endemic in Mexico. This patient's travel history to Mexico is a risk factor for the development of a hepatic echinococcal cyst (hydatid cyst), and the infection may be asymptomatic for months, presenting with tender hepatomegaly when large enough. However, echinococcal cysts do not cause constipation, fever, or weight loss. A hepatic echinococcal cyst is seen on contrast-enhanced CT scan (CECT) as an anechoic cyst with multiple septations and individual "daughter cysts” within the main cyst. The septations give the cyst a characteristic spoke wheel pattern. This patient's history and CECT with multiple solid, nonseptate lesions that have a peripheral rim enhancement suggest another diagnosis.

questions.text: A 41-year-old man comes to the physician because of several episodes of rectal bleeding over two weeks. He has had pain around the anal area for the past month. Six months ago, he was diagnosed with esophageal candidiasis and was treated with oral fluconazole. He is HIV-positive. He has had nine male sexual partners over his lifetime and uses condoms inconsistently. Vital signs are within normal limits. Digital rectal examination and anoscopy show a hard 2-cm mass palpable 0.5 cm above the anal verge that bleeds on contact. There is no inguinal lymphadenopathy. The abdomen is soft and non-tender. The CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 95/mm3. A biopsy confirms the diagnosis. This patient is most likely to benefit from which of the following interventions?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Radio chemotherapy The patient findings are consistent with anal carcinoma . The incidence of anal cancer is higher in individuals infected with HIV and in men who have sex with men ( MSM ), such as this patient. Anal cancer typically presents as an exophytic, hard anal mass often tender and bleeds easily. The combination of chemotherapy and radiation {Nigro’s regime}is the treatment of choice for patients with anal squamous cell cancer; it is superior to surgery, with a 5-year survival rate of ∼ 80%. Subsequent surgery is only indicated if a residual tumor is confirmed with a biopsy after the completion of radiochemotherapy.

Highyeild:

Anal carcinoma Anal canal carcinoma includes SCC, BCC, and melanoma , with SCC being the most common . Median age at diagnosis is 60 Most common symptom is bleeding from the rectum . Most frequent site of metastasis is the lungs , and the most common site of lymph node metastasis is the inguinal lymph nodes. Risk factors include HPV infection (types 16, 18, 31, and 33), HIV or immunosuppression, smoking, anal receptive intercourse, sexual promiscuity, chronic inflammation, anal intraepithelial neoplasia, and a history of vulvar or cervical cancer. Other symptoms may include pain, incontinence, changes in bowel habits, pelvic pain, and rectovaginal or rectovesical fistulas. Diagnosis is usually made through proctoscopy with biopsy, with CT of the abdomen and pelvis used to evaluate distant metastasis.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Abdominoperineal resection (APR) is indicated in certain patients with low-lying rectal adenocarcinomas that cannot be treated with sphincter-sparing procedures and those with adenocarcinomas of the anal canal. Adenocarcinomas of the anal canal, however, are rare and not the most likely diagnosis in this young patient without a family history of colorectal cancer or other predisposing factors like inflammatory bowel disease, smoking, or alcohol consumption. Option: C. Local cytostatic treatment with 5-fluorouracil is indicated in patients with anogenital warts (i.e., condylomata acuminate). Although anogenital warts may manifest as painful lesions, like those seen in this patient, they usually present as cauliflower-like lumps, not a hard mass, and rectal bleeding is a rare sequela. Option: D. Total mesorectal excision is usually performed with low anterior resection in patients with rectal adenocarcinoma. However, the patient's tumor is just above the anal verge, within the anal canal, rather than the rectum. In addition, adenocarcinoma is unlikely in a young patient without predisposing factors such as a family history of colorectal cancer, inflammatory bowel disease, smoking, or alcohol consumption.

Extraedge:

Treatment of choice is chemoradiation with the Nigro regimen, which cures more than 80% of patients. Chemotherapy typically involves 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) plus mitomycin C or cisplatin, followed by radiotherapy. Overall 5-year survival rate is 66%.

questions.text: A 61 year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive fatigue and dyspnea on exertion for three months. During this time, he has also had increased straining during defecation and a 10-kg weight loss. He has no personal or family history of serious medical illness. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor. Laboratory studies show microcytic anemia. The test of the stool for occult blood is positive. A colonoscopy shows an exophytic mass in the ascending colon. Pathologic examination of the mass shows a well-differentiated adenocarcinoma. A gain-of-function mutation in which of the following genes is most likely involved in the pathogenesis of this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

KRAS The patient has right-sided colorectal cancer. Most sporadic cases of colorectal carcinoma arise from the chromosomal instability pathway (i.e., the adenoma-carcinoma sequence ). A loss-of-function mutation of the tumor suppressor gene APC in this pathway results in decreased intercellular adhesion and increased epithelial proliferation. Next, a gain-of-function mutation in the KRAS proto-oncogene results in unregulated cellular signaling and cellular proliferation , predisposing to adenoma formation. Finally, loss-of-function mutations of additional tumor suppressor genes (e.g., TP53, DCC) result in the malignant transformation of an adenoma to carcinoma.

Highyeild:

Colorectal cancers develop from adenomatous polyps through genetic mutation s influenced by environmental factors. The adenoma-carcinoma sequence is a well-supported theory based on observational evidence. Still, the progression of mutations is a complex series of genetic alterations that eventually lead to an invasive tumor. APC gene mutations occur early in the process of carcinogenesis, while K-ras mutations are later events and are more frequently found in larger lesions. The p53 gene is frequently mutated in carcinomas but not in adenomas and is considered a marker of invasion. An international consortium has identified four consensus molecular subtypes (CMSs) of colorectal cancer based on gene expression analysis: CMS1 (sporadic MSI), CMS2 (WNT and MYC signaling activation), CMS3 (metabolic dysregulation), and CMS4 (transforming growth factor beta activation).

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. A loss-of-function mutation (not a gain-of-function mutation) in the tumor suppressor gene Deleted in Colon Cancer (DCC ) is a late event in the chromosomal instability pathway (i.e., the adenoma-carcinoma sequence). It promotes the malignant transformation of an adenoma into a carcinoma. Option: B. A loss-of-function mutation (not a gain-of-function mutation) in the tumor suppressor gene TP53 is a late event in the chromosomal instability pathway (i.e., the adenoma-carcinoma sequence). It promotes the malignant transformation of an adenoma into a carcinoma. Normally, TP53 is activated in response to DNA damage and ultimately inhibits G1-S progression and allows DNA repair to occur. TP53 can also activate apoptosis if DNA damage is irreparable. Mutations in TP53, therefore, result in unregulated progression through the cell cycle and the accumulation of genetic errors. Loss-of-function mutations in TP53 are associated with most human cancers and Li-Fraumeni syndrome. Option: C. The microsatellite instability pathway is characterized by a loss-of-function mutation (not a gain-of-function mutation) or epigenetic silencing (i.e., promoter hypermethylation) of mismatch repair genes, including MLH1 and can result in the development of colorectal carcinoma. This mechanism underlies Lynch syndrome. However, it is an uncommon cause of sporadic cases of colorectal carcinoma

questions.text: A 67 year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of dizziness, fatigue, and shortness of breath. He has noticed increased straining with bowel movements and decreased caliber of his stools over the past three months. He has no history of medical illness and takes no medications. He appears pale. Physical examination shows mild tachycardia and conjunctival pallor. The test of the stool for occult blood is positive. His hemoglobin concentration is 6.4 g/dL, and his mean corpuscular volume is 74 μm3. A double-contrast barium enema study in this patient will likely show which of the following?

options.label: B
options.text: Lead pipe sign of descending colon

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Filling defect of rectosigmoid The patient's manifestations are most likely due to underlying colorectal cancer. The rectosigmoid colon is the most commonly involved site of colorectal carcinoma, followed by the ascending colon and the descending colon. Lumen constriction caused by circumferential tumor growth results in a characteristic apple core lesion-filling defect in a double-contrast barium enema study. Colorectal carcinoma should be suspected as an underlying cause of iron deficiency anemia in men > 50 years of age and postmenopausal women. Left-sided colorectal carcinomas , which involve the rectosigmoid colon and the descending colon, are more likely to cause obstructive symptoms (e.g., straining during defecation, decrease in stool caliber) than right-sided colorectal carcinomas, which involve the ascending colon .

Highyeild:

Manifestations in a patient may be due to underlying colorectal cancer. Rectosigmoid colon is the most commonly involved site of colorectal carcinoma. Lumen constriction from tumor growth can result in an apple core lesion-filling defect in barium enema study. Colorectal carcinoma should be suspected as a cause of iron deficiency anemia in certain patient groups. Left-sided colorectal carcinomas are more likely to cause obstructive symptoms than right-sided ones. Regular screening is important for those at high risk for colorectal cancer. Risk factors for colorectal cancer include personal or family history, inflammatory bowel disease, and lifestyle factors. Treatment typically involves surgery and may include chemotherapy or radiation. Early detection and treatment can greatly improve outcomes.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Thumbprint sign is caused by bowel wall thickening and is associated with several conditions, including ischemic colitis and inflammatory bowel disease. These conditions typically cause abdominal pain and diarrhea, which this patient does not have. Moreover, ischemic colitis does not cause obstructive symptoms (e.g., straining during defecation, decrease in stool caliber). Patients with recurrent exacerbations of Crohn disease can develop obstructive symptoms due to stricture formation, but the development of these complications in a patient with no prior history of Crohn disease exacerbations is unlikely. Option: B. Lead pipe sign on double-contrast barium enema is a characteristic finding in patients with ulcerative colitis. This condition can develop in older adults and cause iron deficiency anemia due to chronic bleeding. However, this patient lacks classic manifestations of ulcerative colitis, such as bloody diarrhea with mucus, abdominal pain, and tenesmus. Moreover, this condition does not typically cause obstructive symptoms (e.g., straining during defecation or decreased stool caliber). Option: C. Diverticular disease, typically in the sigmoid colon, commonly affects older adults. Diverticulosis can cause iron deficiency anemia due to chronic bleeding. Patients with recurrent diverticulitis can develop obstructive symptoms (e.g., straining during defecation, decrease in stool caliber) due to inflammatory stenosis and subsequent stricture formation. However, this patient has no history of diverticulitis, which typically manifests with fever, left lower quadrant pain, and leukocytosis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP)?

options.label: A
options.text: More than 80% of patients have a positive family history

options.label: B
options.text: The condition is inherited as an autosomal recessive condition

options.label: C
options.text: If there are no adenomas by the age of 30 years, FAP is unlikely

options.label: D
options.text: Restorative proctocolectomy with an ileal pouch is the preferred surgical treatment

questions.correct_answer: B. The condition is inherited as an autosomal recessive condition
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The condition is inherited as an autosomal recessive condition FAP is. Inherited as an autosomal dominant condition. In FAP, more than 80% have a positive family history. The remaining 20% result from new mutations in the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) gene. For families, there should be a screening policy in place. Genetic testing should be offered in the early teens; from the teenage years, an annual colonoscopy should be carried out.

Highyeild:

Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP) FAP is diagnosed by over 100 colorectal adenomas, duodenal adenomas, and other extraintestinal manifestations. FAP is mostly caused by positive family history, but new mutations in the APC gene can also cause it. FAP is an autosomal dominant condition that affects both men and women equally. Individuals with APC gene mutation have a lifetime risk of colorectal cancer of up to 100%. FAP can also be associated with benign mesodermal tumors such as desmoid tumors and osteomas, and epidermoid cysts can also occur. Regular endoscopic surveillance is necessary; screening should begin at 12-14 years old.

Random:

Explanation For Other Options:- Option: A, C & D. These are correct statements.

Extraedge:

Examination of blood relatives is essential, and referral to a medical geneticist is necessary. If over 100 adenomas are present at colonoscopy , the diagnosis of FAP can be made confidently. Surgery is usually deferred until 17-18 unless symptoms develop, and malignant change is uncommon before age 20.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man is diagnosed with colorectal cancer. Which of the following statements is false regarding the disease?

options.label: B
options.text: At the time of diagnosis, one-third will have liver metastases

options.label: C
options.text: 20% of patients present as an emergency with intestinal obstruction

options.label: D
options.text: Reduced dietary fiber is associated with an increased risk

questions.correct_answer: A. Almost 60% occur in the caecum
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Almost 60% occur in the caecum The most common site (60%) of colorectal cancer is the rectosigmoid region . This is thought to be due to the prolonged contact of the feces with the mucosa in that region. It, therefore, follows that the majority will be within reach of the rigid sigmoidoscope so that a biopsy can be obtained in the outpatient department.

Highyeild:

Dukes' staging for colorectal cancer Invasion of but not breaching the muscularis propria Breaching the muscularis propria but not involving lymph nodes Lymph nodes involved Dukes himself never described a stage D, but this is often used to describe metastatic disease

Random:

Explanation For Other Options:- Option: B, C & D. are correct statements.

Extraedge:

The American Cancer Society recommends screening for colorectal cancer through annual fecal hemoccult testing and flexible sigmoidoscopy every five years for asymptomatic individuals with no colorectal cancer risk factors. Alternatively, a " total colon examination " such as a colonoscopy or double-contrast barium enema every ten years can also be used. Colonoscopy is preferred over double-contrast barium enema as it has higher sensitivity for detecting villous or dysplastic adenomas or cancers. Double-contrast barium enema may be used as an alternative when colonoscopy is contraindicated.

questions.text: A 17 year-old man is advised to see his physician because genetic screening has detected the disease in other family members. On physical examination, a stool sample is positive for occult blood. A colonoscopy is performed, followed by a colectomy. The figure shows the gross appearance of the mucosal surface of the colectomy specimen. Microscopic examination shows these lesions are tubular adenomas. Molecular analysis of this patient’s normal fibroblasts is most likely to show a mutation in which of the following genes
questions.explanation:
Solution:

APC This young patient’s colon shows hundreds of polyps. This is most likely a case of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) syndrom e, resulting from the inheritance of one mutant copy of the APC tumor-suppressor gene. Every somatic cell of this patient most likely has one defective copy of the APC gene. Without treatment, colon cancers arise in 100% of these patients because of the accumulation of additional mutations in one or more polyps, typically before 30 years of age.

Highyeild:

Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP) FAP is diagnosed by over 100 colorectal adenomas, duodenal adenomas, and other extraintestinal manifestations. FAP is mostly caused by positive family history, but new mutations in the APC gene can also cause it. FAP is an autosomal dominant condition that affects both men and women equally. Individuals with APC gene mutation have a lifetime risk of colorectal cancer of up to 100%. FAP can also be associated with benign mesodermal tumors such as desmoid tumors and osteomas, and epidermoid cysts can also occur. Regular endoscopic surveillance is necessary; screening should begin at 12-14 years old.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Patients with a gene for hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal carcinomas, such as MLH1 and MSH2, also have an inherited susceptibility to developing colon cancer, but in contrast to patients with FAP, they do not develop numerous polyps. Option: C & D. Sporadic colon cancers may have CpG island hypermethylation along with KRAS mutations, whereas others have p53 mutations, but the somatic cells of patients with these cancers do not show abnormalities of these genes.

Extraedge:

Examination of blood relatives is essential, and referral to a medical geneticist is necessary. If over 100 adenomas are present at colonoscopy , the diagnosis of FAP can be made confidently. Surgery is usually deferred until 17-18 unless symptoms develop, and malignant change is uncommon before age 20.

questions.text: A 42 -year-old woman has had increasing abdominal distention for the past 6 weeks. On physical examination, an abdominal fluid wave and bowel sounds are present. Paracentesis yields 1000 mL of slightly cloudy serous fluid. Cytologic examination of the fluid shows malignant cells consistent with adenocarcinoma. Molecular analysis of these cells shows an MSH2 gene mutation with microsatellite instability. She doesn't have any previous medical history. Her sister was diagnosed with endometrial cancer, and her brother had stomach carcinoma. Which of the following conditions most likely cause this patient’s symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lynch syndrome Of the conditions listed, the one most likely to lead to adenocarcinoma in a patient of this age is hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer, or Lynch syndrome . Crohn's disease is unlikely because the patient has not had a prior serious illness, and Crohn's disease of long duration is unlikely to remain asymptomatic. Although adenocarcinoma may complicate Crohn's disease, it does not occur as frequently as ulcerative colitis. The other conditions listed are not premalignant.

Highyeild:

Lynch syndrome Lynch syndrome is a hereditary condition that increases the risk of colorectal cancer and several other types of cancer. It is caused by a mutation in one of four DNA mismatch repair genes, which leads to microsatellite instability and acceleration of the adenoma-carcinoma sequence. Individuals with Lynch syndrome tend to develop colorectal polyps at an early age and have a lifetime risk of 80% for developing cancer. Lynch syndrome is diagnosed based on a family history of cancer and clinical criteria and can be confirmed through genetic testing. Those with a gene mutation should receive regular endoscopic surveillance from a young age, and extended colectomy may be necessary in some cases. Screening for other areas of the gastrointestinal tract is unclear, but gynecological screening is recommended.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A,B & C. These conditions are not premalignant.

Extraedge:

Immunohistochemistry can identify MMR proteins or MSI in all colorectal tumors. Genetic testing can be done in patients and families with a confirmed positive result. Surveillance recommended for carriers of Lynch syndrome: 2-yearly endoscopic surveillance for MLH1 and MSH2 carriers from age 25, and 5-yearly screening for PMS2 carriers from age 35. Extended colectomy is considered for patients with polyps or cancer that cannot be managed with endoscopic polypectomy. Early surveillance and intervention can help manage the accelerated pathway to cancer in Lynch syndrome.

questions.text: A 31 -year-old man has a routine health maintenance examination. A stool sample is positive for occult blood. On colonoscopy, a 6-cm ulcerative lesion is seen projecting into the cecum. There are three smaller sessile lesions from 1 to 3 cm in size. The microscopic appearance of a section of the ulcerated lesion shows adenocarcinoma. The smaller lesions are reported as sessile serrated adenomas. Which of the following molecular biological events is thought to be most critical in developing such lesions?

options.label: C
options.text: Germline transmission of a defective RB1 gene

questions.correct_answer: B. Defective DNA mismatch repair gene
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Defective DNA mismatch repair gene The lesion is an adenocarcinoma . Such a lesion in a 30-year-old man strongly indicates a hereditary predisposition. One hereditary form of cancer is called hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC), resulting from defective DNA mismatch repair genes. He could have taken NSAIDs inhibiting COX-2 expressed in most colonic and carcinomas. In contrast to familial adenomatous polyposis syndrome, HNPCC does not lead to the development of hundreds of polyps in the colon.

Highyeild:

Lynch syndrome Lynch syndrome is a genetic condition previously known as hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC). It is an autosomal dominant condition caused by a mutation in one of four DNA mismatch repair genes ( MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, and PMS2 ). Lynch syndrome increases the risk of colorectal cancer and cancers of the endometrium, ovary, stomach and small intestine, urinary tract, pancreas, prostate, and kidney. Faulty DNA mismatch repair genes lead to microsatellite instability (MSI) and acceleration of the adenoma-carcinoma sequence. Individuals with Lynch syndrome tend to develop colorectal polyps at an early age that quickly become cancerous. The lifetime risk of developing cancer in individuals with Lynch syndrome is 80% . questions.text: A 51-year-old man comes for a health maintenance visit. He feels healthy, exercises regularly, and eats a balanced diet. Medical history is notable only for a remote appendectomy; the patient takes no regular medications. His father had a myocardial infarction at age 68, and he has no family history of cancer. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination findings are normal. The patient is referred for a screening colonoscopy, revealing a single 7-mm pedunculated polyp in the sigmoid colon. The polyp is completely removed by snare excision. Which histopathological findings would require the most intensive follow-up colonoscopic surveillance?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Villous adenoma Colon polyps are grossly visible protrusions from the flat mucosal surface of the intestine. They can be categorized as neoplastic and non - neoplastic . Adenomas (adenomatous polyps) are considered neoplastic polyps; findings that suggest a greater risk of malignant transformation (usually warranting more aggressive colonoscopic surveillance) include: Predominance of villous features (long glands on histologic examination), particularly in the presence of high-grade dysplasia Large size (e.g., > 1 cm) High number (e.g., > three concurrent adenomas) In addition, sessile adenomatous polyps are associated with an increased risk of synchronous advanced neoplasm and often require careful follow-up to ensure complete removal.

Highyeild:

Neoplastic polyps , including adenomatous polyps, are common in individuals over 50 years old in the US, affecting up to 25% of the population. Adenomatous polyps are defined as dysplastic . Malignant transformation risk is dependent on the type and size of the polyp. Tubular adenomas have a low association with cancer (5%), while villous adenomas have a higher likelihood of harboring cancer (up to 40%). Tubulovillous adenomas have an intermediate risk (22%). Invasive carcinomas are rare in polyps smaller than 1 cm , and the incidence of invasive carcinoma increases with size . The risk of carcinoma in a polyp larger than 2 cm is 35% to 50%.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A, B & C. Non-neoplastic polyps, including hyperplastic polyps, hamartomatous inflammatory pseudopolyps, and submucosal polyps, have low malignant potential and generally do not require enhanced surveillance. In general, the malignant potential of villous adenomas is greater than that of tubular adenomas.

Extraedge:

Most colorectal cancers originate from a polyp , even though most neoplastic polyps do not progress to cancer. Secondary prevention strategies aim to eliminate colorectal cancer by removing neoplastic polyps before malignancy develops.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false regarding colorectal cancer?

options.label: A
options.text: Aging is the dominant risk factor for colorectal cancer, with the incidence rising steadily after age 50 years

options.label: B
options.text: Colorectal carcinoma occurs more commonly in populations that consume diets low in animal fat and high in fiber has led to the hypothesis that dietary factors contribute to carcinogenesis

options.label: C
options.text: Patients with long-standing colitis from inflammatory bowel disease are at increased risk for the development of colorectal cancer

options.label: D
options.text: Pelvic irradiation may increase the risk of developing rectal carcinoma

questions.correct_answer: B. Colorectal carcinoma occurs more commonly in populations that consume diets low in animal fat and high in fiber has led to the hypothesis that dietary factors contribute to carcinogenesis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Colorectal carcinoma occurs more commonly in populations that consume diets low in animal fat and high in fiber has led to the hypothesis that dietary factors contribute to carcinogenesis The observation that colorectal carcinoma occurs more commonly in populations that consume diets high in animal fat and low in fiber has led to the hypothesis that dietary factors contribute to carcinogenesis. A diet high in saturated or polyunsaturated fats increases the risk of colorectal cancer, while a diet high in oleic acid does not increase the risk. Animal studies suggest that fats may be directly toxic to the colonic mucosa and thus may induce early malignant changes. In contrast, a diet high in vegetable fiber appears to be protective.

Highyeild:

Colorectal cancer prevalence is closely associated with the intake of red meat and processed meat products containing haem and N-nitroso compounds. Dietary fiber may have a protective effect against colorectal cancer. Increased roughage in the diet is thought to reduce colonic transit times, leading to reduced exposure of the mucosa to dietary carcinogens. The colonic microbiota may also contribute to the development of colorectal cancer through inflammation, gene methylation, and dysplastic changes. Smoking and alcohol consumption increase the risk of colorectal cancer. High intake of magnesium and calcium may be protective against colorectal cancer. The potential protective role of antioxidants such as vitamin E and selenium is yet to be proven.

Random:

Explanation For Other Options:- Option: A, C & D. All other statements are true.

Extraedge:

Involvement of lymph nodes by the tumor typically progresses from the nearest lymph nodes along the lymphatics to central nodes, but this process may not always occur in an orderly manner Hematogenous spread of colon cancer commonly occurs to the liver via th e portal vein One-third of patients have liver metastases at diagnosis, and 50% develop metastases at some point, accounting for the majority of deaths The lungs are the next most common site of metastatic disease Spread to the ovaries, brain, kidney, and bone is less common Colorectal cancer can also spread from the serosa of the bowel or via subperitoneal lymphatics to other structures within the peritoneal cavity, such as the peritoneum, ovary, and omentum

questions.text: A 68-year-old chronic smoker is diagnosed with colorectal cancer. Which of the following statement is false regarding this disease?

options.label: A
options.text: The classic first symptoms are a change in bowel habits and rectal bleeding.

options.label: B
options.text: Right-sided tumors are more likely to obstruct than left-sided tumors.

options.label: C
options.text: Rectal tumors may cause bleeding, tenesmus, and pain.

options.label: D
options.text: Abdominal pain, bloating, and other signs of obstruction typically occur with larger tumors and suggest more advanced disease

questions.correct_answer: B. Right-sided tumors are more likely to obstruct than left-sided tumors.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Right-sided tumors are more likely to obstruct than left-sided tumors. Symptoms of colon and rectal cancers are nonspecific and generally develop when the cancer is locally advanced. The classic first symptoms are a change in bowel habits and rectal bleedin Abdominal pain, bloating, and other signs of obstruction typically occur with larger tumors and suggest more advanced disease. Because of the bowel's caliber and the stool's consistency, left-sided tumors are more likely to obstruct than right-sided tumors. Rectal tumors may cause bleeding, tenesmus, and pain.

Highyeild:

Colorectal carcinoma commonly spreads via regional lymph node involvement before distant metastasis or carcinomatosis occurs. Factors such as tumor size , poorly differentiated histology , lymphovascular invasion, and depth of invasion increase the likelihood of nodal metastasis. The T stage, which refers to the depth of invasion , is the most significant predictor of lymph node spread. Carcinoma in situ (Tis) has no risk of lymph node metastasis. Small lesions confined to the bowel wall (T1 and T2) are associated with lymph node metastasis in 5% to 20% of cases . Larger tumors that invade through the bowel wall or adjacent organs (T3 and T4) are likely to have lymph node metastasis in over 50% of cases. The number of lymph nodes with metastases correlates with the presence of distant disease, indicating a more advanced disease. Left-sided tumors are more likely to obstruct right-sided tumors due to the bowel's caliber and the stool's consistency. Rectal tumors may cause bleeding, tenesmus, and pain. Many patients may be asymptomatic and present with unexplained anemia, weight loss, or poor appetite.

Random:

Explanation For Other Options:- Option: A, C & D . These are correct statements.

Important risk factors for primary hepatocellular carcinoma include chronic hepatitis B and C infections. Immunohistochemistry can identify MMR proteins or MSI in all colorectal tumors. Genetic testing can be done in patients and families with a confirmed positive result. questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician due to fatigue and weight loss. Over the last six months, he has lost 9 kg and can no longer walk long distances without resting. The patient has not seen a physician in 15 years. He has smoked a pack daily for 35 years but does not use alcohol or illicit drugs. Temperature is 36.9 C {98.4 F), blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg, the pulse is 88/min, and respirations are 12/min. Lungs are clear to auscultation, and abdominal examination shows a liver span of 14 cm with no tenderness. Rectal examination reveals normal sphincter tone but a slightly enlarged prostate non-tender to palpation. A Chest x-ray is unremarkable. CT scan of the abdomen is shown in the image below. Which of the following is most likely to establish the diagnosis in this patient

options.label: B
options.text: Aspiration and culture of liver lesion

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Colonoscopy This patient with weight loss and fatigue has multiple liver lesions on the CT scan, suggesting metastatic disease to the liver rather than primary liver cancer. Colorectal cancer is the most common source of liver metastases (as blood from the colon moves through the portal circulation directly to the liver) and should be excluded in this patient, even in the absence of specific symptoms (e.g, alteration in bowel habits, gastrointestinal bleeding). Abdominal CT is a useful screening test but can often miss primary intraluminal tumors. Colonoscopy is the most appropriate next diagnostic step as it both localizes the tumor and provides a tissue diagnosis. Lung and breast cancers also metastasize to the liver , although less commonly than gastrointestinal malignancies. This patient is a smoker However, he has a normal chest x-ray and no respiratory symptoms, making metastatic lung cancer unlikely.

Highyeild:

Metastatic Colorectal Carcinoma refers to the spread of cancer cells from the colon or rectum to other parts of the body, most commonly the liver. Historically, the prognosis for patients with metastatic colorectal cancer has been poor . Advancements in chemotherapy and surgical techniques have increased the number of patients who are now candidates for hepatectomy , which involves the surgical removal of a portion of the liver. Preoperative chemotherapy has been shown to convert some patients with the unresectable disease to complete resection, increasing their chances for long-term survival. Combinations of chemotherapy and complete resection of hepatic metastases have been associated with long-term survival in up to 50% of patients in modern series.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Alpha-fetoprotein measurement is used along with imaging studies in the diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma, which most commonly occurs in the setting of chronic liver disease and presents as a solitary mass. Option: B. With pyogenic liver abscesses , aspiration, and culture can guide antibiotic therapy. However, abscesses typically present acutely with fever, right upper quadrant pain, anorexia, and weight loss. Serologic studies can be distinguished between pyogenic and amebic liver abscesses. Option: C. Bone marrow biopsy is useful in diagnosing myeloproliferative or lymphoproliferative disorders . It would be uncommon for these disorders to cause multiple liver masses.

Extraedge:

Complete resection of hepatic metastases is considered a critically important treatment modality for long-term survival in patients with metastatic colorectal carcinoma. The management of metastatic colorectal carcinoma is complex and individualized based on factors such as the extent of the disease, the patient's overall health, and the response to treatment.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman complains of being ‘out of sorts’ for almost 3 months. During this time, she has felt unduly short of breath in doing her daily household work and going up one flight of stairs. Her hemoglobin is 8.6 g/dL, and her general practitioner felt a vague mass in the right iliac fossa. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Carcinoma caecum Patients with caecal carcinoma can present as an emergency or electively due to the primary tumor or metastatic disease such as liver secondaries. The presentation is from features of iron deficiency anemia due to chronic occult bleeding or pain and lump over the right side of the fossa. Patients present with symptoms due to metastatic disease. This can be in the form of jaundice due to liver secondaries.

Highyeild:

Caecal carcinoma patients can present as an emergency or electively. Elective presentations can be due to the primary tumor or metastatic disease, such as liver secondaries. Common symptoms include iron deficiency anemia due to chronic occult bleeding, pain, and a lump over the right side of the fossa. Metastatic disease can cause symptoms like jaundice due to liver secondaries. Symptoms can vary depending on the stage of the disease and other individual factors. Carcinoma of the caecum or ascending colon is treated by right hemicolectomy.

Sometimes there is a history of colicky abdominal pain due to impending obstruction. Option: C. Despite taking laxatives, there has been no improvement. He has occasional bright-red rectal bleeding when he strains at stool. Examination reveals no abnormality. He is pale. A barium enema picture is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient?

Solution:

Carcinoma of descending colon The presentation is change in bowel habit in the form of increasing constipation because the stools are formed, and the bowel lumen in the descending colon is narrow. Sometimes there is a history of colicky abdominal pain due to impending obstruction. There is also a change in caliber of stool. A barium enema image shows an apple core appearance .

questions.text: A 63-year-old male patient presents with diarrhea and fresh rectal bleeding for one month. He experiences occasional abdominal pain and loss of appetite. Select the best diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Rectal carcinoma Common symptoms of colorectal cancer include a change in bowel habits (persistent constipation or diarrhea lasting more than three weeks), rectal bleeding (blood in the stool or the toilet after having a bowel movement), dark or black stools, cramping or discomfort in the lower abdomen, decreased appetite, unintentional weight loss, and fatigue . The risk of this cancer increases with age.

Highyeild:

Rectal carcinoma : The rectum is the most common site for colorectal cancer , with adenocarcinoma being the most common type. Multiple tumors can be found in 5% of cases. Carcinoma rectum usually presents as an ulcer , but polypoid and infiltrating types are also common. Carcinoma rectum typically presents in patients above 55 years of age . Bleeding is the earliest and most common symptom, while a sense of incomplete defecation may also be present. Back pain or sciatica can occur when cancer invades the sacral plexus . Weight loss is suggestive of hepatic metastases .: Sigmoidoscopy (rigid, not flexible) and biopsy are the investigations of choice for the diagnosis of carcinoma rectum. TRUS (Transrectal ultrasound) is best for T staging . Endorectal coil MRI best predicts lymph node invasion and overall staging . CECT is used for the evaluation of metastasis .

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Diverticulitis - presents with persistent lower abdominal pain . There may be accompanying diarrhea and constipation. Option: C. Crohn’s disease is an inflammatory bowel disease characterized by transmural inflammation that can affect the entire gastrointestinal tract from the mouth to the anus. The initial pathology is the formation of aphthous and serpiginous ulcers with normal intervening mucosa that appear nodular and is called cobblestone mucosa . A barium meal establishes the extent of the disease and follow-through, showing a string sign of Kantor . Option: D. Ulcerative Colitis - The usual sufferer is a female between 30 and 40 years who complains of loose stools with blood and mucus. Sometimes she has to rush to the toilet and might be caught short. Anything up to 4 to 6 trips to the lavatory daily leaves her constantly feeling insufficient evacuation and tenesmus. Colicky left-sided abdominal pain usually accompanies loose stools . Barium enema shows the classical shortened pipe-stem colon .

Extraedge:

The most common sites of metastasis of rectal carcinoma are the liver (34%) , lungs (22%) , and adrenals (11%). The standard radiotherapy dose given in rectal carcinoma is 60 Gray .

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Right hemicolectomy Carcinoma of caecum or ascending colon is treated by right hemicolectomy

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Left Colectomy - For lesions or disease states confined to the distal transverse colon, splenic flexure, or descending colon, a left colectomy is performed. Option: C. Transverse Colectomy - Lesions in the mid and distal transverse colon may be resected by ligating the middle colic vessels and resecting the transverse colon, followed by a colocolonic anastomosis.
